p:
Blood and cellular composition and levels are regulated by multiple factors, such as lipid intake
17â€“ 19 , gut microbiota
20 , microRNAs (e.g., miR-33 and miR-122)
21 , and regulatory proteins, e.g., sterol regulatory element-binding proteins, liver X receptors, p53, and AMPK
22, 23 . Further, plasma transport of lipids like TAG, phospholipids, cholesterol, and CE occurs in complexes with apolipoproteins, creating lipoproteins, which can be classified into high-density lipoproteins (HDL), intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDL), low-density lipoproteins (VDL), and very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL)
24 . In addition, the transport of fatty acids occurs in association with other proteins, such as albumin
25 . Therefore, variation in the genes encoding lipid-associated proteins may have a large effect on lipid regulation and disease outcome.
